subject: Technology
title: Robert Goddard's First Rocket
description: A 60-second lesson on Robert Goddard's First Rocket.

hook.text: In 1926, Robert Goddard launched a tiny rocket from his aunt's farm in Massachusetts. It flew for 2.5 seconds.

buildup.text: The rocket reached 41 feet. About the height of a three-story building. Neighbors were unimpressed.

discovery.text: But Goddard had proven liquid fuel could power a rocket. Nobody had ever done that before.

twist.text: The New York Times mocked him, saying rockets couldn't work in a vacuum. They printed a retraction in 1969.

climax.text: Every rocket that has ever reached space, from Apollo to SpaceX, builds on Goddard's liquid fuel design.

punchline.text: A 2.5-second flight on a farm started the space age.

quiz.question: What did Robert Goddard prove with his 1926 launch?
options: Liquid fuel could power a rocket
